Short Description: Increase fees related to audit and third-party certification services
Details:
Federal-State Cooperative Agreement with USDA requests that fees charged for audit services conducted under that agreement follow the current federal rate, currently at $92/hr. OAR-603-053 currently puts the Oregon Department of Agriculture out of compliance with this agreement. Increased revenue generated from this fee increase will help pay for administrative costs of the program, as well as yearly continuing education for auditors and accreditation and audit fees for certification programs.

The ODA proposes a revised fee schedule as follows: change the minimum hourly charge from $75 to $92, with a 4 hour minimum of service. Additionally, it proposes application fees for the National Organic Program certification program at $250 for new organic applicants and $100 yearly renewal application fee for returning customers to cover the administrative cost and accepting and reviewing organic applications before inspection and audit fees can be billed. Additionally, as the Department has begun to offer Global Food Safety Initiative benchmarked audits, a certification fee is proposed to be charged per certificate to cover technical review and administrative costs of this program.

Short Description: the meeting agenda includes a budget report, discussion of funding priorities, Regional Advisory Council appointment, project aplication revies, and other program business
Details:
ODFW’s Access and Habitat Board will meet Tuesday, April 24 the Chinook Winds Hotel 1501 NW 40th Place Lincoln City, OR 97367. The meeting begins at 8:00 a.m.

The meeting agenda includes a budget report, discussion of funding priorities, Regional Advisory Council appointments, project application reviews, and other program business.
Members of the public may attend the entire meeting. An opportunity for public comment is scheduled for 10:00 a.m.

A field trip to view local projects funded by the A&H Program is scheduled for Monday April 23. The tour will leave at 8:00 a.m. from the Chinook Winds Hotel 1501 NW 40th Place Lincoln City, OR 97367. Members of the public may accompany the group using their own transportation.

A teleconference line is also available for members of the public who wish to participate in the Tuesday meeting, but who cannot attend in person. Contact Matt Keenan at (503) 947-6087 for teleconference phone number and access code.

The A&H Program funds projects that provide hunter access and/or improve wildlife habitat on private land in Oregon. The A&H Program is funded primarily by a $4 surcharge on hunting licenses, big game auction and raffle tag sales. 

For additional information on attending the meeting or field trip call program staff at 503-947-6087. More information about the A&H Program can be found at www.dfw.state.or.us/lands/AH.
Public Comment Accepted: An opportunity for public comments is scheduled for 10:00 AM

Short Description: The agenda includes reports on STEP activities and projects, program updates and review of mini-grant applications.
Details:
SALEM, Ore. — The Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife’s Salmon and Trout Enhancement Program (STEP) Advisory Committee will meet in Reedsport on Friday, April 13, 2012.

The committee will meet from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. at the Umpqua Discovery Center located at 409 Riverfront Way in Reedsport. The agenda includes reports on STEP activities and projects, program updates and review of mini-grant applications. The meeting is open to the public.

The Committee also will review a proposal to renew the Gardiner-Reedsport-Winchester Bay STEP propagation program. Any STEP project that rears fish for release (including egg incubation) must be approved by ODFW. Part of the approval process includes public input and review by the Advisory Committee.

The proposals are available for public review on the ODFW website at http://www.dfw.state.or.us/fish/STEP/ and members of the public will be able to comment on the proposals at the meeting or in writing. Written comments are due by April 9.

The Oregon Legislature created STEP in 1981 to provide a way for volunteers to participate in the restoration of native stocks of salmon, steelhead and trout. Since then, thousands of volunteers have donated money, materials, equipment and countless hours of labor to improving Oregon fisheries. 

The STEP Advisory Committee makes recommendations to ODFW and the Fish and Wildlife Commission on issues regarding its programs. The committee’s 13 members are appointed by the Governor and represent all areas of Oregon.

Reasonable accommodations will be provided as needed for individuals requesting assistive hearing devices, sign language interpreters or large-print materials. Individuals needing these types of accommodations may call the Information and Education Division at (800) 720-6339 or (503) 947-6002 at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting. 

For more information on the Salmon Trout Enhancement Program visit the ODFW Web site at http://www.dfw.state.or.us/fish/STEP/ or call program staff at (503) 947-6211.

Short Description: The agenda includes a program and budget update, review of new project proposals and other program business.
Details:
SALEM, Ore.— The Oregon Department of Fish and Wildlife’s Fish Restoration and Enhancement Board will meet on Friday, April 20 at the Clarion Inn, 1249 Tapadera Ave., Ontario.
 
The Board will meet from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. The agenda includes a program and budget update, review of new project proposals and other program business.
 
The meeting is open to the public, and there will be an opportunity for public comment in the afternoon.
 
On Saturday morning, April 21, the Board will tour local R&E projects. Members of the public may accompany the group but must provide their own transportation. For additional information on the field trip, contact R&E Program staff at (503) 947-6259.
 
Reasonable accommodations will be provided as needed for individuals requesting assistive hearing devices, sign language interpreters or large-print materials. Individuals needing these types of accommodations may call the Information and Education Division at 800-720-6339 or 503-947-6002 at least 24 hours in advance of the meeting.
 
Created by the Oregon Legislature in 1989, the Fish Restoration and Enhancement Program is funded by a surcharge on sport and commercial fishing licenses and commercial poundage fees. The program’s seven-member citizen board reviews fish restoration and enhancement project proposals and makes funding recommendations to the Oregon Fish and Wildlife Commission.
 
For more information on the Fish Restoration and Enhancement Program, or to view information regarding current R&E Program applications, visit www.dfw.state.or.us/fish/RE or contact program coordinator Josie Thompson at (503) 947-6259.

Short Description: Advise and Discuss Issues Pertaining to the Oregon Trauma System
Evidence-based Guidelines, Value-based Benefits, Coverage Guidance, ICD-10-CM
Meeting Location: Legacy Meridian Park Hospital, Room 117B&C, 19300 SW 65th Ave
Details: The Commission will hear a report from the Value-based Benefits Subcommittee on recommended changes for the ICD-10 conversion of lines on the Prioritized List for a number of different specialty areas and other recommended changes to the list discussed at the Subcommittee’s March and April meetings.  In addition, they will consider recommendations from the Evidence-based Guidelines Subcommittee on advanced imaging for low back pain and percutaneous interventions for low back pain as well as coverage guidance recommendations on elective induction of labor and non-pharmacologic/non-invasive interventions for the treatment of low back pain.  The Commission will continue to discuss the potential adoption of a conflict of interest form for members and may also discuss potential additional topics for evidence-based guideline, health technology assessment and coverage guidance development.
Public Comment Accepted: Public comment is welcome but may be limited due to time constraints.

The Subcommittee will also review public comments on the 1) guidances on elective cesarean section and nonpharmacologic treatments of low back pain and 2) guidelines for advanced imaging for low back pain and percutaneous interventions for low back pain and finalize them for consideration by the full commission.

Short Description: Rulemaking corrects alleged procedural irregularities related to rules prohibiting internal combustion motorboats/floatplanes on Waldo Lake.
Meeting Location: Willamalane Park & Recreation   District, Willamalane Center   Ken Long Rm.  250 S 32nd St.
Details:
The agency proposes to re-adopt OAR 250-020-0221 and 250-030-0030 in order to correct alleged procedural irregularities related to their previous adoption. Those rules implement the Oregon Scenic Waterway Act by prohibiting internal combustion motorboats and floatplanes on Waldo Lake, a statutorily designated state scenic waterway, in order to preserve the natural setting of Waldo Lake, minimize disturbance of its natural beauty, protect its aesthetic values, and provide an unimpaired quality of recreational experience. An exception is provided in the rules for official governmental use and emergency landings of floatplanes. 

In a rule challenge pending in the Oregon Court of Appeals, Columbia Seaplane Pilots Assoc. v. State Marine Board, Oregon Court of Appeals Case No. A148192, certain procedural irregularities have been alleged, including the assertion that the fiscal impact statements for the challenged rules were inadequate. In order to provide an opportunity to correct the alleged procedural irregularities related to the previous rule adoption, the agency is initiating further rulemaking to enable the Board to take action on the basis of new fiscal impact statements and other relevant information. Such action could potentially take the form of re-adopting the rules, amending the rules to modify the prohibition of internal combustion motorboats and floatplanes on Waldo Lake, or repealing the rules.

The executive session is being held pursuant to ORS 192.660(2)(f) which allows a governing body to hold an executive session to consider information or records that are exempt by law from public inspection.

Representatives of the news media, OEBB staff and individuals specifically invited to participate are allowed to attend this executive session. Representatives of the news media are specifically directed not to report on any of the deliberations during executive session, except to state the general subject of the session as previously announced. No decision may be made in executive session.

Meeting Location: PEBB/OEBB Boardroom, Department of Administrative Services ÛÒ General Services Building, 1225 Ferry Street SE

Meeting Title: Oregon Parks and Recreation Commission Meeting
Meeting Location: Red Lion Hotel, 200 N Riverside Ave, Medford Oregon
Details:
Oregon Parks and Recreation Commission meets in Medford

 

Medford, OR -- The Oregon State Parks and Recreation Commission will meet in southern Oregon April 3-4. The governor-appointed commission will tour the Rogue River Greenway and participate in an internal workshop in Gold Hill on April 3 from 8:30 a.m.– 4:30 p.m.. On April 4, the group will conduct a public business meeting starting at 10 a.m. at the Red Lion Hotel Medford, 200 N. Riverside Avenue, Medford.

Agenda items include All Terrain Vehicle committee member appointment requests and an action to recognize Brian Booth, the first commission chair, who passed away March 7, 2012 at age 75. The agenda also includes time for public comments. Speaking time is limited to three minutes. People who wish to speak are encouraged to provide 12 written copies of their testimony to Vanessa DeMoe, the Commission Assistant (vanessa.demoe@state.or.us) prior to the meeting. The full agenda is posted at http://www.oregon.gov/OPRD/commission.shtml

State law gives the commission authority to establish policy and adopt rules for Oregon Parks and Recreation Department, approve property acquisitions for state parks, and set fees for the use of park facilities. Its seven members are appointed by the governor and confirmed by the Oregon Senate.

The meeting site is accessible to people with disabilities. Special accommodations may be arranged up to 72 hours in advance by calling 503-986-0719.

•	Respond to hazardous materials incidents

Short Description: Regular meeting of the Winter Recreation Advisory Committee
Details: The Winter Recreation Advisory Committee meets throughout the year to advise the Department of Transportation on matters related to the winter recreation parking (Sno-Park) program.  At this meeting the committee will consider a request from the Deschutes National Forest to expand the Virginia Meissner Sno-Park.  The committee will also discuss the Sno-Park permit fees and make a recommendation on the level of enforcement of the permit for the 2012-13 winter season.
